  return torch._C._cuda_getDeviceCount() > 0
{% endraw %}

Currently only Vision and Tabular models are supported. More details on this technology can be found on the official pytorch documentation

Motivations:

  • What is torchscript? What is a serialized model?
  • Why one would like to export a model to another format?
  • Is it faster?
{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

There are two possible scenarios with jit: trace and script.

  • torch.jit.trace when the module has no flow control/ dynamic behaviour. (e.g. modules build with nn.Sequential).
  • torch.jit.script should be utilized when there are dynamics. (e.g. RNNs, Language models). As a result trace is tried by default. You can also have a combination of both.

from Pytorch doc:In many cases either tracing or scripting is an easier approach for converting a model to TorchScript. Tracing and scripting can be composed to suit the particular requirements of a part of a modelScripted functions can call traced functions. This is particularly useful when you need to use control-flow around a simple feed-forward model. For instance the beam search of a sequence to sequence model will typically be written in script but can call an encoder module generated using tracing.

Most of vision encoders are `traceable's.

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class JitMode[source]

JitMode(*args, **kwargs)

All possible export modes as attributes to get tab-completion and typo-proofing

{% endraw %}

Another important thing to consider, is the serving device. If you plan on doing inference on CPU, yoou should first convert you model to CPU, and then trace-it (ref)

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

Learner.to_jit[source]

Learner.to_jit(fname='export.ts', mode='trace', device='cpu')

Exports learn.model using jit with mode to fname

{% endraw %}

Below you will find a number of examples using Learner.to_jit and loading them back in

Tabular (Multi-Input)

{% raw %} 
from fastai.tabular.all import *
path = untar_data(URLs.ADULT_SAMPLE)

dls = TabularDataLoaders.from_csv(path/'adult.csv', path=path, y_names="salary",
    cat_names = ['workclass', 'education', 'marital-status', 'occupation',
                 'relationship', 'race'],
    cont_names = ['age', 'fnlwgt', 'education-num'],
    procs = [Categorify, FillMissing, Normalize])

learn = tabular_learner(dls, metrics=accuracy)
{% endraw %}

Tabular models can only be exported with torch.jit.trace, so we'll use that:

{% raw %} 
(Path.cwd()/'models').mkdir(exist_ok=True)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
learn.to_jit('models/tab.pt', mode=JitMode.Trace, device='cpu')
{% endraw %}

Now we can load it back in using raw torch and pass in a batch of data:

{% raw %} 
loaded_model = torch.jit.load("models/tab.pt")
cat,cont,_ = dls.cpu().one_batch()
{% endraw %}

And perform inference:

{% raw %} 
probs = loaded_model(cat,cont); probs[:3]

tensor([[-0.0424,  0.0352],
        [-0.0509,  0.0218],
        [-0.0334,  0.0130]], grad_fn=<SliceBackward>)
{% endraw %}

As these are just the models, raw probabilities are returned. You still need to perform a soft or argmax

Vision

Below is an example using ResNet:

{% raw %} 
from fastai.vision.all import *
path = untar_data(URLs.PETS)/'images'
def label_func(x): return x[0].isupper()
dls = ImageDataLoaders.from_name_func(
    '.', get_image_files(path), valid_pct=0.2,
    label_func=label_func, item_tfms=Resize(224))
learn = cnn_learner(dls, resnet18)
{% endraw %}

Since ResNet is a vision model, trace should be used:

{% raw %} 
learn.to_jit('models/resnet.pt', mode=JitMode.Trace)
{% endraw %}

Just as before we can now load it in and perform inference:

{% raw %} 
loaded_model = torch.jit.load("models/resnet.pt")
loaded_model.eval()
x,_ = dls.cpu().one_batch()

probs = loaded_model(x); probs[:3]
{% endraw %}
